BE11:13am

Stifel:

11:13 am
BE11:13am

First order competitor impacts. With ~600k customers overseas, more than 20,000 jobs and 105 aircraft, the disruption from TC's collapse will have far reaching and long-lasting implications:

The big negative could be On the Beach (Hold, 380p 20/09 close) who relies on TC aircraft seats to fulfill its package holidays. We believe TC accounts for around 15% of OTB’s UK flight capacity. When Monarch Airlines went bust in 2017, TC took a £2m hit as reduced seat availability pushes up market prices. We think the impact from TC's failure will be multiples of this. OTB has put out an RNS this morning (with no numbers) citing a one-off exceptional cost for FY19, and potential impact to (underlying) performance in FY20. Analyst call scheduled for 8:30am.
The big positive could be Dart Group (Buy, 846p) who operators Jet2holidays and Jet2.com. With considerable customer overlap we see Dart as TC's closest competitor, who should be a beneficiary once the dust starts to settle - partly in the Midlands.
We also see TUI (Buy, 841p) as a beneficiary in its Markets & Airlines business which, for the same reasons at TC, has been under pressure recently. The removal of a major competitor should help to alleviate these difficulties.

BE11:13am

The longer-term impact of TCs failure will depend in large part on how much capacity is redeployed amongst competitors, and how much leaves the industry. We estimate TC accounts for about 2.5% of UK to Europe aircraft capacity which, if it was all to leave the industry, could help support a more rational competitive environment for the industry. In reality many of TC's airport slots will be attractive to competitors, hence some of the capacity is likely to be backfilled (as was the case with Monarch)

TUI (Buy) has expressed an interest in participating in industry consolidation, and has in the past been linked to TC's German Airline Condor.
easyJet (not covered) is looking to develop its easyJet Holidays packaged holiday offering

2s10s @BE: Are we over holidayed? (like in overbanked?, like in excess capacity)
BE11:14am

(@2s10s: I'm not.)

2s10s haha
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Barclays:

BE11:15am

The group has c.22,000 group employees and c.150,000 customers currently on holiday with Thomas Cook. The UK government and CAA are reportedly working to repatriate customers. In terms of readacross to the sector, we see a positive readacross to TUI from reduced competition and potentially reduced capacity in key territories (UK, Germany, Nordics). We estimate that if TUI gained £2bn of lost TCG revenue it would be worth an additional c.4% to TUI’s FY20 EBITA (assuming a 2.4% margin). However, whilst the benefit to TUI could be material, the issues TCG has faced only serve to highlight how challenged the tour operating business is from a structural perspective. So while TUI may benefit, investors are unlikely to immediately become fully comfortable owning TUI, particularly given the immediate uncertainties ahead (e.g. Brexit).

BE11:15am

Simplistically, we estimated that if TUI gained £2bn of lost TCG revenue, and assuming a margin of 2.4%, this would be worth an additional 4% to FY20 EBITA for TUI. However, the benefit could be wider as a Thomas Cook exit would reduce pricing pressure in the tour operator market and potentially reduce capacity within the airline market (assuming capacity is removed rather than replaced, albeit we note that Condor appears to be flying today), particularly in Germany, a problem often highlighted by TUI’s CEO. This could ultimately lead to higher operating margins on TUI’s existing tour operating business. We think that Thomas Cook has c.30% of the packaged holiday market in the UK (excluding OTAs and low-cost carrier airlines) and c. 10% in Germany, with TUI a little higher in both regions. Elsewhere, we note the statement from On the Beach this morning that the company is assisting customers currently in resorts or whose travel plans will be affected which will result in one-off exceptional costs associated with helping customers to organise alternative travel arrangements, and lost margin on cancelled bookings.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Morgan Stanley:

2s10s or was it Brexit?
BE11:17am

There are various implications for incumbent operators and we think a net positive for TUI: First, the collapse of such a well known holiday brand may damage customer confidence in package holiday operators. However, the industry has seen many holiday companies collapse in the past (including market leaders ILG in 1991, MyTravel in 2003, and nearly Thomas Cook in 2013) and survived. We note that this is a quiet period for holiday bookings, and the industry should have settled down by the new year “peak” season when summer holiday bookings ramp up. We also note that TUI rebranded from Thomson a few years ago, one reason being the name’s close similarity to Thomas Cook. Second, the collapse may raise questions over the package holiday business model. Package holidays are threatened by disintermediation from low cost carriers and online travel agents, and traditional operators tend to have high legacy retail, technology and overhead costs.

BE11:17am

Thomas Cook, like TUI, was remixing its business towards more hotels more under its control and brands, but the impact of airline overcapacity, a demand shift from the Eastern to Western Med, last year's hot weather, and significant debt burden are also just as much to blame. Demand for package holidays has actually held up well over the last decade (as indeed have the revenues of Thomas Cook and TUI) [...] This reflects the benefit they offer to customers such as their all inclusive nature, ATOL protection, and ease of booking (see our positive survey earlier this year here). Tour operating constitutes ~5% of TUI’s EBIT in FY19e (depressed by the MAX grounding costs) and ~25% in FY20, so the majority of profit comes from its higher margin, content heavy Hotels and Cruise businesses.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Third, the collapse could remove excess capacity from the oversupplied leisure airline and package holiday market, which would bring some relief to the remaining operators. It remains to be seen how much capacity goes, as the collapse of Monarch and Air Berlin simply saw those aircraft subsumed into their competitors. However, Thomas Cook is significantly larger than these two, its airline is run separately from its tour operator, and its brand has lost significant goodwill with customers, so we doubt its existing scale will survive. Thomas Cook has 22m passengers, and an estimated 11% market share of the package holiday market in the UK and 13% in Germany ....

BE11:19am

As for the airlines ....

RBC:

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Thomas Cook's exit overnight follows those of Aigle Azur (France),
XL Airways (France - ceased trading) and Adria (Slovenia) that is
still trading but seeing aircraft repossessed. Aeronews today notes
loses at TAP Air Portugal mean the government is looking for a 'new
shareholder'.
• This autumn shake-out is earlier than usual (late October/November
tends to be the airline liquidity low-point). While distressing news for
passengers and holidaymakers, longer-term an earlier shake-out likely
leads to less risk of irrational fare pricing (cash flow raising rather than
profit making) affecting this winter.

Forester I for one am damn glad the government did not spend my money to bail out a badly run & indebted company with a terminally ill business model. And before anyone says "what about RBS bailout?"....please! There was a major risk to the whole financial system!
BE11:20am

T Cook is 1-3% of scheduled capacity: OAG estimates suggest T Cook
was 1.5-1.6% of UK winter European capacity and

3% summer. Intra-

Europe it was less than 1% in winter and 1-2% in summer, though pure charter flights might not be captured by OAG.
• Even before this, winter looked constructive: As we had already noted
on 13/09/2019, German winter European scheduled capacity was set
for -2.8% YoY, total intra-European scheduled capacity set for +0.6% YoY
(below GDP growth), and capacity to/from the UK was +0.8% YoY - so
likely -1% after today.

BE11:21am

Back filling likely by next summer though: We see no obvious single
buyer for the T Cook slots (and Monarch's raised little anyway, with
some at Manchester left initially unfilled). We see it more likely that
a range of companies will seek to pick off opportunistic assets. So, for
example, easyJet, IAG (if BA has bandwidth beyond solving a confused
brand, IT challenges and industrial unrest), and Jet2 (DTG LN) might find
use in some of the London slots and overnight stand-allocation rights,
Ryanair/Lauda will likely have interest at Dusseldorf and Manchester,
while Lufthansa may have some interest in Munich slots. Thus capacity
will likely not die off, but return in a different form.
• For easyJet we think this does suggest a more rational winter is ahead,
but beyond that, how slots and capacity is recycled back into the market
will be key. History here suggests that capacity will not disappear, but
return in just a slightly more consolidated form.

· Thomas Cook accounted for 1.4% of seats in the shorthaul European market in 2018 and in 2019e, and as much as 2% in the summer months, according to scheduled capacity.

· Of the 103 planes overall, 35 are based in the UK, 54 in Condor and the balance in Nordics, whilst the seat capacity split can be seen in the pie chart below.

· Their key airport bases include Frankfurt (10.1% of own capacity, 402 slots), Dusseldorf (4.6%, 232 slots), Manchester (8.1%, 352 slots), Gatwick (5.0%, 208 slots).

· Thomas Cook’s market share at these airports is as follows; Frankfurt (4.2%), Manchester (8.9%), Gatwick (3.5%) and Dusseldorf (5.2%). Share at other top 10 airports is depicted below.

· As well as opportunity for holiday peers such as TUI, Jet 2 and On the Beach to take further share of the package holiday market, the overlap with the airlines is largest for Lufthansa (Eurowings), easyJet and Ryanair.

BE11:35am

4 The eurozone composite output PMI fell from 51.9 to 50.4 (consensus: 52.0), its lowest level since June 2013. In terms of headline PMIs, both manufacturing and services fell. Manufacturing was down 1.4pts to 45.6 (defying expectations consensus of a rise to 47.3).
Services fell from 53.5 to 52.0 vs consensus of a smaller 0.2pt fall.
4 Within manufacturing, there was a further fall in new orders and employment intentions, both of which are firmly below 50. Backlogs of work fell for the ninth time in the past ten months.
4 As for services, the employment intentions index fell but remains above 50. New business fell to its lowest level since January. And after a 4pt plunge last month, business expectations only rebounded by half a point.

2s10s @Fh worst since 2009

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous people
BE11:36am

4 The main driver of the eurozone fall appears to have been Germany. After ticking up last month and being in a 43-45 point range since March, the German manufacturing PMI took another drop in September, to 41.4. This is the lowest level in more than a decade and in stark contrast to consensus expectations of a half point rise.
4 Compounding the German misery, the services index also fell from 54.8 to 52.5. This was its lowest level since December and confirms the concern signalled by last month's services business expectations sub-index (which fell sharply in August) that manufacturing woes are spilling over into the service sector (something also indicated by the ifo survey).
4 Combined, these falls took the German composite output PMI to 49.1, an 83-month low and below 50 for first since April 2013.

Fh @nichoman probably waiting for the next election

11:36 am
BE11:37am

(@Sprout: yep, sorry. Misreading.)

BE11:37am

Today's PMIs make grim reading, particularly for Germany. Since the peak of the German manufacturing PMI in December 2017, there have been a few occasions where a signs of stabilisation have been snuffed out. The latest falls have added a new leg down after a period of relative stability since the end of Q1. With the PMIs now signalling a deeper German manufacturing contraction and increasingly showing the manufacturing sector infecting the service sector, the risk of outright German recession is high.
The fall in the French PMIs show that it can't be counted on to maintain reasonable growth as Germany's woes intensify. Indeed, Markit now estimate the eurozone economy could grow by just 0.1% in Q3. With the eurozone close to stagnation and Germany contracting, the ECB must consider its next move. While it is hoping fiscal stimulus might ride to the rescue, it can take nothing for granted. Even with its economy stuttering, we think a large structural German stimulus is still unlikely given the politics.

Mouselet hornblower: If the TC planes still belonged to TC, TC would be a functioning company; they're reverted to the lessors and getting them back at short notice is apparently more difficult than hiring separate ones?

And Commerzbank:

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Today's figures confirm one thing in any case: there will be no noticeable improvement in the economy this year. On the contrary, the risk of a recession is increasing. For Germany in particular, a so-called "technical recession" - i.e. a decline in real GDP for two consecutive quarters - is very likely. With the deterioration of the situation in the services sector, however, the danger of a pronounced recession, i.e. a shrinking economy with a significant decline in investment and a noticeable rise in unemployment, is also increasing, especially in Germany.

Mr Neumann’s outsized influence over the company has become one of the biggest hurdles in the path of a multibillion-dollar IPO, according to investors and people briefed on the matter.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Mr Singer is another piece in considerable management change at M&S in recent years. Over the last three years material new talent has been brought in under Messrs Norman and Rowe as the Group seeks to engineer necessary structural adjustment, noting the recent relegation of M&S' stock from the FTSE-100 as a signal of the need to notably self-improve. Having a capable and settled team is a pre-requisite to planning and executing effectively transformation, especially one as wholesale and enormous in its extent as that at M&S.

We do sense that there has been a notable improvement in the capability of the Group's senior team albeit the departure of Jill McDonald (Clothing & Home [C&H] Managing Director) and now the pending exit of Mr Singer, mean that there are still two key roles that need to be effectively filled; Mr Rowe took on the direct C&H responsibility as a new divisional Managing Director is sought. With respect to the CFO role, whilst the adjustment was not within our central expectation as FY2020 commenced, we are comforted that Mr Singer is keeping his hands on the functional steering wheel in the near term and contributing to the succession process.

BE11:50am

Whilst all this is ongoing, M&S needs to more effectively trade its business on an ongoing basis to meet medium-term transformation targets, something that we expect to be the focus of the Group's Capital Markets morning on the 1st October 2019. In this respect we harbour encouragement as to operational progress in the Group's Food division, encouragement reflected in our store visits and augmented by some improved recent secondary market share data points (e.g. Nielsen).

As for C&H, well the lead times mean that immediate improvement is harder to engineer, whilst the UK apparel market has been tough for most of CY2019, reflected in extensive market commentary, not presently assisted by a quite warm September, whilst M&S closing full assortment stores and sustaining operating challenges does little to positively drive share at this time.

As such, we believe that the Capital Markets morning is an opportunity for M&S to engage with the market more in a doing rather than analysing and transformation planning mode; something we sense that its investors will welcome.

All this said, however, the transformation programme remains a medium-term course of activity, reflected in our flattish earnings and re-based dividend expectations out to FY2022. Success in driving a stronger financial performance could, however, do with the two key senior management roles being effectively filled as soon as possible. As such we will look out for forthcoming appointments in due course.

BE11:51am

M&S's medium term transformation will, like the Sagrada Família, be finished one day. But probably not in our lifetimes.

BE11:55am

RSA Insurance Group plc - Feeling valued is key to a truly inclusive culture - Public Technologies

23-Sep-2019 10:36:28

We all have a role to play in this. Everyone must be willing to be more open, curious and to truly look beyond the surface. With a clear vision and by taking things a step at a time, an organisational culture can change for the better.

During Dive In and Inclusion Week, think about the impact you can have on others, reach out to someone you don't know well, listen, ask questions, challenge your initial judgement on a person or a situation and above all as be open and curious as you can.

That's when you achieve an inclusive culture that enables people to feel valued and enables allows individuals to shine. As Maya Angelou says, make sure you do something that makes people remember how you made them feel.

Sports Direct is the largest shareholder in Goals, with an 18.93% shareholding. Goals has had some well-publicised difficulties and its shares are currently suspended from trading on AIM. Absent any extension of the suspension it is expected that Goals' trading facility on AIM will be cancelled on 30 September 2019, per Goals' announcement on 2 August 2019. Sports Direct has requested the board of Goals provide customary due diligence materials. Despite the Possible Offer and request for information being communicated to the board of Goals on 5 September 2019, the board has so far failed to provide any such information to Sports Direct. Sports Direct has urged the Goals board to engage with it in discussing the Possible Offer and providing the requested information. This deal, if it proceeds and finalises, is a very sensible one as SPD's core target customer is very similar to that of Goals with some 100,000 customers/week. Underperforming sites could be boosted by a Sports Direct store, and the installation of gyms. That said current trading (2 August 2019), GOAL, announced that in the year-to-date sales across the 45 sites in the UK on a gross like-for-like basis are up +11.5% and that US gross like-for-like sales are up +14.5%, and there were positive discussions with debt lenders too.
